channel.title: External HDD broken
channel.description:
About half a year ago I bought a SATA hdd and an external hdd case, with it's own adapter (so no power via USB). I put them together myself, and it worked fine. Until today. I turned it on, listened to some music and all of the sudden the external hdd crashes. So I bash on it for a while, put the power cord in some different plugs etc... To find out whether the hdd was broken or it didn't get any power, I put the hdd in my desktop. Luckily, it worked. So it doesn't get any power.
So my question is: What is more likely, is the cord/adapter broken or something inside the case? Do I have to replace the cord or the complete case?

item.title: External HDD broken
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I’ve been searching a bit, and found this:

USB 2.0 IDE + SATA cable converter
Support for USB 1.0 / 2.0.

Plug&Play.
Power Cable converter
SATA Cable (40cm)
Power adapter.
AC Power Adapter input :
100 ~ 240V, 50/60HZ, 2A
AC Power Adapter output :
12V/2A, 5V/2A .
Support PC/ Mac OS/ Notebook Support.
OS : Win98SE, 2000, ME, XP, Mac OS 10 or higher.

1x USB to IDE/SATA cable
1x power supply
1x Power Supply Cord
1x Power Cable converter
1x SATA Cable (40cm)
1x English Manual

How’s that? It’s only €11,95.

Read full topic

item.description:

R.I.P RSC:

How will replacing the SATA > USB adapter fix the power problem?

I meant solder the power cable.

item.title: External HDD broken
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:5, topic:282313”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=373032.msg2814910#msg2814910 date=1244229082]
Rip it out of the cage and replace the SATA -> USB adapter.
[/quote]

I’ll still need a way to connect it to my laptop so I can access the files on it.

But I did find out it is the power cord. Thing is, the local computer guy said replacing the cord would cost as much as getting a new case.[/quote]
He’s retarded, go grab a soldering iron.

Read full topic
